feed.subtitle: Write an awesome description for your new site here. You can edit this line in _config.yml. It will appear in your document head meta (for Google search results) and in your feed.xml site description.

entry.title: Structure and Near-source Behavior of a Highly Active Aftershock Sequence

link.title: Structure and Near-source Behavior of a Highly Active Aftershock Sequence

entry.content:
I present a high-resolution near-source catalog for the aftershock sequence of the 2020 \(M_w\) 6.5 Monte Cristo Range Earthquake (MCRE) built from a to-date untapped nodal deployment. This catalog not only illuminates previously unobserved structure and spatiotemporal evolution of the aftershock sequnece, it also primes us to explore near-source properties that are often underobserved due to the paucity of high quality near-source data within seismology.

3D view of locations on proposed slip plane from Li et al. 2021 and surface fault traces from Kariche 2022 . Nodal deployment is shown in yellow. Nevada Seismological Laboratory broadband stations are shown in orange.

See SSA ('25) presentation abstract
See SCEC ('25) poster presentation
entry.summary: I present a high-resolution near-source catalog for the aftershock sequence of the 2020 \(M_w\) 6.5 Monte Cristo Range Earthquake (MCRE) built from a to-date untapped nodal deployment. This catalog not only illuminates previously unobserved structure and spatiotemporal evolution of the aftershock sequnece, it also primes us to explore near-source properties that are often underobserved due to the paucity of high quality near-source data within seismology.

entry.title: Earthquake Clustering in the Japan Subduction Zone

link.title: Earthquake Clustering in the Japan Subduction Zone

entry.content:
I am looking at earthquake clustering in one of the most complete earthquake catalogs in the world, the Japan Meteorological Agency Catalog (JMAC). I apply a nearest-neighbors clustering method developed by Zaliapin & Ben-Zion , looking to scale the approach from a point-source model (which cannot be reliably assumed for larger earthquakes) to one which can incorporate fault plane length and focal mechanisms.

Nearest neighbors clustering applied to a subset of the JMAC demonstrating the limitations of a point-source assumption at large magnitude events like the \(M_{w}\) 9.1 2011 Tohoku earthquake. This may be true for smaller events too (note that the “streaking” over short rescaled time intervals and large rescaled distance intervals remains visible pre-Tohoku).

See AGU ('24) presentation abstract
entry.summary: I am looking at earthquake clustering in one of the most complete earthquake catalogs in the world, the Japan Meteorological Agency Catalog (JMAC). I apply a nearest-neighbors clustering method developed by Zaliapin & Ben-Zion , looking to scale the approach from a point-source model (which cannot be reliably assumed for larger earthquakes) to one which can incorporate fault plane length and focal mechanisms.
